div1.p: Lucile and I have read your letter of April 30 again and again, and we are deeply gratified that you have been able to reconcile the event with your philosophy. As I know from sad experience, one's philosophy does not always serve in the time of tribulation.

I write now to invite, not to urge you to come to 211 Westmount for a visit as extended as you care to make it just as soon as we get back to Columbia. Wevplan now to arrive on June 8. Apart from our understandable wish to have you as a guest, we have another consideration in mind. You and Lucile have quite a task to perfom. To get you into a book will not be easy. You are so incredible that some people find it difficult to believe you in the flesh---besides which printer's ink is pale stuff indeed. (I re,member Elmer Ellis' true account of the astonished remark made by a distinguished scientist after he had heard one of your programs: "Why, he really believes it!").

If you are to be put into a book, you and Lucile will have a lot of talking to do. This coming summer will doubtless be outr last period in Columbia--we may never be able to get back. Our house is now up for sale, with occupanycy offered Setptember 1. I believe that the two of you should have every opportunity to talk freely, fully, lengthily, and conveniently. You could be quite comfotablecomfortable in our guest room, which has all the conveniences including a bath; and you may count on Lucile to serve your favorite dishes. I think her book--and yours--will be a good, even perhaps a great one; and I think the book needs the kind of conversation that could take place if you were with us.

To get the full import of my invitation, tyou should rwead again the "Phaedrus"--particularly the section beginning at 275 et seq., in which Plato has Socrates expound the superiority of the spoken over the written word. The book will have to be written; but the writing can be ever so much better if good talk precedes the writing. See S.H. Butcher's Some Aspects of the Greek Genius (Macmillan: London, 1893), especially chapter on "The Written and the Spoken Word", p. 177 et seq. I hope you will plan to stay a while with us. If I may say so, I think you and Lucile owe it to the book of Neihardt.

postscript.p: We are grateful for the letter from your daughter, Hilda. Now we know as much as we need about the earthly side of the matter: the accident, the incredible error of the physician, the hopes and fears. As to the other side, the spiritual, we have no fears.
